topic.title: Is ZeroBoard really decentralized?
topic.body:
I was looking at the ZeroBoard source code and it seems like new messages are added through a PHP file hosted at the zeronet.io site, doesn't seem to be really decentralized.

I guess it works like that because it doesn't require the users to have a ZeroId and the PHP is kind of a proxy, but I couldn't tell.

topic.title: The Robbery - small game
topic.body:
I built this game a few years ago, it's kind of old but still fun to play. My record is at 150 coins, how many can you get?

http://127.0.0.1:43110/14zQjCbU2BAy3uAUAXN5UJhq8YdAHyzUqK/the-robbery/index.html

topic.title: ZeroFrame plain JavaScript examples
topic.body:
Are there any ZeroFrame plain javascript examples? The documentation only includes the examples in CoffeeScript.

I think it's easier to get started with plain javascript as not all of us know CoffeScript or have the time to learn it.

topic.title: ZeroNet sites takedown
topic.body:
ZeroNet sites are harder to take down than regular web sites, but couldn't a ZeroNet site be taken down if the author is forced to remove the contents?

The author could be forced to just replace the contents of his site with an empty file and that would be pushed to everyone hosting it, so the site would still exist but the contents wouldn't. Is that what would happen or am I wrong?

topic.title: ZeroWiki: a wiki for ZeroNet?
topic.body:
Ok, so this is my first ZeroNet project and it's bit of an experiment, let me know if it works for you.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP

topic.title: ZeroNet: @keyframes breaks CSS compilation?
topic.body:
I'm trying to add some animations to a ZeroNet website but I'm having some issues with the automatic compilation/merge ZeroNet does to the CSS files.

It seems like when I'm adding a @keyframes rule without prefixes, ZeroNet compiles it and automatically adds browser prefixes, however, it's producing broken CSS with missing closing brackets which breaks the whole CSS.

Has anyone else experienced this? I'm on ZeroNet 0.3.6.

topic.title: Development workflow for ZeroNet sites
topic.body:
What's the recommended workflow to develop ZeroNet sites? I'm wondering if it's a good idea to have a "development" site and a "production" site, or if just makes sense to keep developing new features on the "production" version of the site.

How do you manage git repos in your the ZeroNet projects? do you publish them with the site or do you include them in the ignored files of content.json? I'm still trying to figure out a workflow that makes sense.

topic.title: Where to buy bitcoins?
topic.body: Where do you buy your bitcoins? can you guys recommend some sites?

topic.title: Kopi: Boilerplate for ZeroNet web applications
topic.body:
This is an early version, help to improve it is appreciated.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1KtzUsnmwc1Wr7KWWEGnWzmBSQoyH917Pz/

The idea is to have a site we can clone to start new ZeroNet projects with default settings, usual methods, documentation and examples to make ZeroNet sites development easier and faster.

It is based in the ZeroChat tutorial and right now is very basic. Feel free to make suggestions and push improvements, the source code is available in this repo:

https://github.com/ZeroNetLabs/kopi

1_1CcJZEvu57ZqSDjWDEJCAGEWzHQ7uXKKNR.body:
We should make it easier to set up, with a step-by-step guide like crypton said, also more information for developers or anyone who wants to publish new stuff in ZeroNet.

The only resource I could find is the official documentation http://zeronet.readthedocs.org which is still pretty basic.

1_1HcCbQWH3xuquT5Z2S4nTk7fqAyoM2AWpi.body: Even though crypton is right I find the UI to be confusing, what are those options supposed to do?

1_18NAazqd14AcVXdCqN29NTUrxSLGyPy5gB.body:
> [ekaterina](#comment_76_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): No, ZeroNet doesn't support big files right now (only about 1 Mb, but the actual limit is a timeout for downloads, if a download takes longer it's canceled) and it's unclear if it ever will since so many people use Tor with ZeroNet and that would waste Tor's already small amount of bandwidth. Might have to integrate with an additional decentralized network focusing on file storage, like IPFS or Storj (and I'm sure there are more, lots of interest in this tech now) for streaming and downloading bigger files.

Is the tor bandwidth the only reason we can't stream big files over ZeroNet? I guess if we were to use IPFS over tor we would have the same issue then.

Video and audio streaming is quite popular on the regular web, and being able to have it decentralized with ZeroNet would be great. In fact, not supporting big files is quite limiting, even some images can easily take more than 1Mb.

1_1LRrd96P7FiTcsyNXVzPM5jtpQoH1B4gYf.body: Right, the source code is on github though https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroBoard

It seems to work for me, give it a try if you like.

> [nofish](#comment_431_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Thanks! I will try it when I have OSX access again.

Could you get the file? It worked before signing and publishing the site, but now I get a "Media referrer error" when I try to download it.

1_1DcDDitsjFJohvwonPmpibRChmA7uGxqL7.body: I've sent you a ZeroMail just now.

1_14WuynvAFSGKrHExccPBC2BiLdh2DF35Ut.body:
It supports .bit domains which are easier to remember.

http://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/faq/#how-can-i-register-a-bit-domain

3_1LRrd96P7FiTcsyNXVzPM5jtpQoH1B4gYf.body: Thanks @ekaterina, I'll give it a try. I still find it easier to start with plain javascript though, at least I don't have to install the coffee compiler or anything else.

3_168qV1Xxp2EyszrzdECLUwXrn9wGYjDdar.body:
> [krlf](#comment_1_18RfVGME7R14BmGRcbVbZ1RaHoaeBEKtZ3): hmm, what if my zeronet server is not on local host (links to games on your page don't work for me ;) )

You're right, I've updated the site and it should be better now. :)

4_1LRrd96P7FiTcsyNXVzPM5jtpQoH1B4gYf.body:
> [nofish](#comment_440_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): If you want persistent content you can delete the site's privatekey, so you then noone able to force you to change it. :)

Right, that would work :)

> [p2p](#comment_61_13Z7XxTa7JuFat3KzzMWu3onwM6biLuurJ): add versioning feature of site's data. any reader of the site can restore it.

Yeah, versioning would be really cool, I think IPFS has something like that. What I like about versioning is that you can link to a resource and be sure it will remain the same even if the author updates it in the future.

Anyway, deleting the private key is good enough to prevent a site takedown, just as a last resort as ekaterina pointed out, because you wouldn't be able to update the site any more.

8_1MEWJRMLgvofqG9Mbsb2Rc4hFFyv7HeRx7.body:
> [angristan](#comment_49_1MEWJRMLgvofqG9Mbsb2Rc4hFFyv7HeRx7): Thx, where do we get the private key ?

ZeroNet will give you the private key when you create the site.

1_17oYQdLkvyzEVPH3hXRtK3ru4FLNKZUD3b.body:
> [lukipuki](#comment_17_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8): I fully agree.I want to be able to censor things for me...

You made a great summary with some cool ideas in this post http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:7_17fgJ3tZjhM7HCkTkd5TWf2BLLWmhRKcXB/Probably+not+a+topic+people+want+to+discuss+in+a+decentralized+arena

However, the upvote/downvote thing with automatic blocking depending on the peers you trust sounds overcomplicated to me. I would be more than fine having an option to block certain users. Once a user got blocked my local copy of ZeroNet should ignore any content coming from him, be it new sites, comments or anything he published in ZeroNet.

Then there's the problem of automatically seeding content. Someone posts a link, you click on it and boom! you're sharing something that may be ilegal in your country. Yeah, sure you can go to your HelloZeroNet page and remove the site, but I'd rather have a new button on every page, similar to the '0' one we have in the top right corner, that allows me to seed/unseed the site I'm currently visiting. This would also allow me to visit sites which I don't necessarily want to seed.

Just my two cents, I know having ideas is easy, executing them is much harder. Nofish has done an impressive work so far and I'm sure he'll come up with better solutions to all this "undesirable content" thing.

14_1PNyuY1iZqXBpft4ArouqcnE4pNRGYij5i.body: Are all sites added manually or do you have some kind of spider adding sites automatically?

2_1DFDjUGJdSp1kMuFq1AtNS9ZWmkVtbp947.body:
This is something that's going to happen as ZeroNet becomes more popular, someone's going to want to know who their users are and how they use the site.

I guess the solution would be to block all the tracking scripts with browser plugins, as we do now in the clear net, or to simply block anything that doesn't come from ZeroNet.

5_1LRrd96P7FiTcsyNXVzPM5jtpQoH1B4gYf.body:
> [ekaterina](#comment_114_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): One word, TotallyAbsolutelyAwesome! :) Looks great, too, really nice and clean design.
> One thing, when I just opened the site for the first time it showed me a dozen or so quickly vanishing messages from ZeroFrame (those that pop up in the top right corner), telling me there were changes to the site, asking me to press "Yes" if I want to load them. I just reloaded the site instead and then everything was fine.

I'm not sure were did they come from, I had some issues with ZeroFrame notifications during development, they seemed to pop-up from nowhere. I'll check it out and see if I find anything that could be causing this. Thank you!

> [basxto](#comment_31_1PVcdu7USZH2kHMETbqDYLPjJZKCDWM52k): Looks great

Thank you!

> I think NullPaste and ZeroTodo are more suitable for that

Sure! use the right tool for the job.

> Let the edit wars begin

Let's do it! :)

> [kaffie](#comment_73_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): I can't seem to connect. Can't connect with the bit.no.com:43110 proxy either. Content.json failed to download.

Not sure why that happens, maybe not enough seeders?

> [erkan](#comment_54_1H8oKiRa7fGgUqS1hpUtaSYLvAqkaknbkf): a question: http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:erkan

I don't have it in a git repo yet, you will need to check the local folder for now, coffee files are included.

> [ekaterina](#comment_115_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): Worked for me. Do you have Tor working? Maybe it has only Tor: Always peers right now. bit.no.com doesn't have a working Tor, so it can only download from peers who have Tor but don't use the Tor: Always setting (Tor: OK instead), those peers work as a bridge between full Tor users and normal users as I understand it.

Yes, maybe it was that, I'm using Tor: Always.

> [zalex](#comment_52_1LWuc6JBhUGrKEAh1aPrPU85dEMcKmg3pS): @cub3, what about protection of home page?

There's no page protection yet, but the "history" feature can be used to recover older versions of the page.

> [kaffie](#comment_74_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): I got it working. No tor for me. I'm guessing that was probably the issue. Either way, I've started contributing to the site. I already made a page for Kaffiene.

Cool, thank you!
